      darsh065
      6 months ago, # ^ |
      ← Rev. 2 →   0

      The order of deletion of characters is given in the question. We can do binary search on the number of characters to deleted. The following invariant can be used:

      If we are able to delete x characters and obtain p, then we can obtain p by deleting x-1 characters.

              jalotra
              5 months ago, # ^ |
                0

              Solve greedily and start from the back. Example : T : shivam P : iam.

              1. Start from the rear end in the string T.
              2. If you get the character that you want(the last character from P), then cool go ahead make found++ and search for the next last character in P.
              3. Else continue the search.

              One more thing here, you will have to take care of deleted indexes.

              darsh065
              5 months ago, # ^ |
                0

              seq = 5 3 4 1 7 6 2 mid = 3

              So mark first 4 chars as let say "-" Now start the comparision of t and p. if t[i] == p[j] then increase the count

              At the end check if count = the length of p , i.e. we found 4 chars which were equal in both, we return True else we return False

              Now if our func return True that means we are able to solve the problem by deleting 4 chars, we should move our right to mid else we move left to mid+1

If this difference is less than EPS1EPS1, then we have our answer. Now we have to iterate until we find a suitable midmid value. We iterate until the difference between highhigh and lowlow is greater than EPS2EPS2. My question is particularly about EPS1EPS1 and EPS2EPS2.         bool good(double x){ double temp=( x*x + sqrt(x) ); if(temp-c>0) return 0; else if(temp-c<=0) return 1; }

        void solve(){ //code goes here cin>>c;

        double l=0;
double r=1e10;

for(int i=0;i<100;i++){
    double mid=(l+r)/2;
    if(good(mid)) {
        l=mid;
    }
    else {
        r=mid;
    }
}
cout<<setprecision(20)<<l<<endl;

    tusharjaiswal
    6 months ago, # ^ |
    ← Rev. 3 →   0
    • First sort the array and then You have to calculate two index:
    • left = index of leftmost element which is greater or equal to l
    • right = index of rightmost element which is less than or equal to r
    • Now your answer will be right — left + 1.

    MayankGusain
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    lets take an eg:_____________________________________________________________________________ _____m = 2; n = 2;________________________________________________________________________________ _____________1st person-> t = 1; z = 1; y = 1;_______________________________________________ _____________2nd person-> t = 1; z = 1; y = 1;_______________________________________________ ______after 1 sec both will have 1 balloon inflated(total 2 balloons). Rest time starts after 1 balloon which is after 1 sec for both but they already have finished the target of 2 balloons by then because of which we need not to consider time they will rest after 1 sec. Hence ans is 1 sec in this case.

#include <bits/stdc++.h>

using namespace std;
long long n,k;
vector<long long> a;
bool good(double c){
    long long g=0;
    for(int i=0;i<n;i++){
        g+=floor((a[i]/c));
    }
    return g>=k;
}
int main() {
 cin>>n>>k;
 a.resize(n);
 for(int i=0;i<n;i++){cin>>a[i];}
 int y=100;
 double l=0,r=1e8;
 while(y--){
     double m=(l+r)/2;
     if(good(m))
     l=m;
     else
     r=m;
 }
 cout<<l<<endl;
}

    → Reply
  • »
    »
    keshavMishr
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0 
    #include<bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
typedef unsigned long long ull;
int n,x,y;
bool isgood(int t) {
	
	return (t/x)+(t/y) >= n-1;

}

int main() {
	
	cin >> n >> x >> y;
	if(n == 1)
		cout << min(x,y);
	else {
		int l =0, r = 1000000000;
		while(r > l + 1) {
			int m = (l + r) / 2;
			if(isgood(m))
				r = m;
			else
				l = m;
		}
	
		cout << r+min(x,y) << "\n";
	}
	return 0;
}

        ← Rev. 2 →   0

        Here is your good function :

        Spoiler
        bool f(ld t)
{   
    ld mini = INF, maxi = -INF;
    FE(i,1,n)
    {
        ld a = x[i] - t*v[i];
        ld b = x[i] + t*v[i];
        mini = min(mini, b);
        maxi = max(maxi, a);
    }
    if(maxi<=mini)
        return 1;
    return 0;
}

175iq
6 months ago, # |
← Rev. 2 →   0

Can someone please help me with the good function of 3-B ?

How do I check if it possible to distribute the given array into k groups so that max possible sum of segment is smaller than S( this is the value on which I am going to do binary search)

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    YoungCody
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    We simply iterate the array a[i] and make segment greedily. If the sum is greater than S, we make a new segment.

    1. If the number of the segment is greater than k, we return false because we can't reduce the number of the segment, or the max sum of segment will be greater than S.

    2. If the number is not greater than k, we just split the segment until the number is k.

In Problem G, how to check if x no. of student councils can be made? pashka

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    shafwanur010
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    Hint: X student groups will have X * K students. From each group you can take at most min(X, A[i]) students.

    → Reply
    • »
      »
      »
      ThePunisher
      6 months ago, # ^ |
        0

      Can u please elaborate little more?

      → Reply
      • »
        »
        »
        »
        shafwanur010
        6 months ago, # ^ |
        ← Rev. 2 →   0

        We want to check if X councils is a valid answer. X councils will have a total of X * K empty slots. It's always optimal to put a student in a council which currently has the least amount of members (you can break down the first example to get the intuition behind this). Unfortunately we can't simulate this, but what we can do is check for each group: the number of councils it's members can be a part of. The answer to this is simply min(X, a[i]).

        Final solution goes like this 

        slots = X * K
for i in range(n):
    slots -= min(X, a[i])
return slots <= 0

How to solve question D — FAST SEARCH in Step 1 practice section? I am getting a TLE in my solution... What is the logic?

→ Reply
  • »

    shreyanshjn
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0
    hint1

    Sort the array, so that you can apply binary search.

    hint2

    Make use of the solutions to Problem B and Problem C. Let the query is x y Find the leftmost index of the element which is >= x. Find the leftmost index of the element which is > y. The answer is the difference between the two indexes.

    hint3

    In CPP you can use lower_bound and upper_bound function. Although, it is better to use a binary search rather than the standard function if you are a beginner.

    0______0
    6 months ago, # ^ |

    sid_00_ You just binary search the answer .let L point to a bad position(ex:0 since we can't make a copie in 0 second). And let R point to a good position (ex:Assume you have only one machine how much time will it take?). And finally make your good function.

    hint

    You just need to know how many copies can you make in t seconds.But there is a little problem .In the first time you can't use both machine so obviously you gonna use the one that take min time.

    Good function code
    int n,x,y;
bool Good(int t)
{
    t-=min(x,y);
    if(t<0) return 0;//We can't even make one single copy in t seconds.
    return (t/x+t/y+1)>=n;//We add one because we already make a copy.
}

          my ac code

          int main()
{
	ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
	cin.tie(0); cout.tie(0);

	ll w, h, n; cin >> w >> h >> n;
	ll s = 0;
	ll e = 1e18;
	ll ans = 1e18;
	while (s <= e)
	{
		ll m = (s + e) / 2;
		ll x = (m / w) * (m / h);
		cout << (m / w) << " " << (m / h) << "\n";
		if (x >= n)
		{
			ans = m;
			e = m - 1;
		}
		else
			s = m + 1;
	}
	cout << ans;
	return 0;
}

heu_ristic
6 months ago, # |
  0

Anyone explain Children holiday(problem D step 2)

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    hackerakhil
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    ya please, can anyone explain it??

    → Reply
  • »
    »
    prayalankar
    6 months ago, # ^ |
    ← Rev. 3 →   0

    Figure out number of balloons person can inflate in time T.

    if person is required to inflate more than z balloon he will take rest so in time T:

    T / (t*z + y ) * z + min( ( T % (t*z + y )/t ) , z )

    i) In above eqn in first part we are finding number of balloons person can inflate in time T with rest.

    ii) Second part we are finding number of balloons in the extra time after taking rest.

    Once you figure that out the problem is reduced to the finding optimal T using Binary search. (Hing T can be min 0 and max 1e9)

NikitosBandos

Hello everybody. Can someone explain how we should find (l, r) in 4-th step problem A? I really have no idea. We just claim that if min_pref[r-d] <= pref[r] so we can find (l,r) in [0, r]. But how?

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    prayalankar
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    As far as I was able to solve . the basic idea is find the r for the max average value possible. Once you find the r from r iterate till 0 and find the max length segment.

    steps

    1. start with mid i.e max value in array ( mid is the max average sum possible)
    2. subtract mid from each element and then calculate pre[i]
    3. use min_pref[r-d] <= pref[r] to check if we can achieve the mid for some r.
    4. if yes increase the mid and try again else decrease the mid and try.

      once found the r for some max_val (i.e mid) iterate from r-d to 0 to check if segment length can be increased.

RakibJoy
6 months ago, # |
  0

Can anyone please give me hint of step 3: B. Splitting an Array ? Thanks in advance.

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    kitsa
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    Try to think greedily. Use binary search to find the value of required sum. Traverse the array from left end until the sum of current segment is greater than mid. If it exceeds mid, split the array at that index and go for a new segment. If number of segments after you reach endpoint doing same traversals is less than or equal to k, this mid value is a good value. Hope that helps..

    → Reply
    • »
      »
      »
      RakibJoy
      6 months ago, # ^ |
        0

      Thank you. Can you please explain why the second step works?

      → Reply
      • »
        »
        »
        »
        kitsa
        6 months ago, # ^ |
        ← Rev. 2 →   0

        Take this example for instance:

        10 4

        1 3 2 4 10 8 4 2 5 3

        Say for a certain case, mid = 19

        So when you're checking whether it can be splitted in 4 parts such that the maximum sum on the segment doesn't exceed 19, you'll have these segments after splitting them greedily from left to right: {1 3 2 4 }, {10 8}, {4 2 5 3}. Since we are left with 3 segments we can make it 4 by spliting further any segment we want, as the sums of new segments must be lesser than 19.

            bool isGood(ll x,vector<ll> arr,ll k) {
    ll no=0;
    ll sum=0;
    bool single = true;
    for(ll i=0;i<arr.size();i++) {
        if(arr[i]>x) {
            single=false;
        }
        if(sum+arr[i]<=x) {
            sum+=arr[i];
        }
        else {
            sum=arr[i];
            no++;
        }
    }
        no++;
    
    return (no<=k&&single);
}

            shnk
            3 months ago, # ^ |
              0

            Yes, this will return true for mid=5, but the answer will be mid=2.

            Spoiler

            Think of segments as 'buckets of equal size' which can be 'filled in order', i.e. if filling bucket 1, can fill this one or move on to filling bucket 2. Then in binary search find the min size of buckets so that all the numbers can still be filled in k buckets without overflowing any bucket.

    Let's say x be the number of maximum council, so there are (x * k) students slots. for each particular group the maximum no of students can take the slot is min(a[i], x) for each ith group. eg sum = x * k; for i 1 to n sum -= min(x, a[i]) return sum <= 0;

    ← Rev. 2 →   0

    1-> an array for v[i]-x values

    2-> prefix sum array of the above array to get the sum of a segment from L to R in constant time

    3-> an min array to store the index of the element with minimum value in the prefix array till ith index

    4-> if (pre[i] >= pre[mn[i — d]]) holds for any segment of length d, u got the segment and its starting index would be mn[i-d]+1.

For the Find closest in array problem, I can think of another approach. 1. First, Find the element for which we want to find the closest 2. Then compare the distance between the left indices and the right indices 3. the lesser the distance, the closes the value is.

In this way, we can solve the later problem with the plain binary search in an array.

Can anyone help me to overcome TLE for B. Minimum Average Path

The approach that I used is as follows:

  • Run a dfs from 1 to n to get the minimum average weight

  • Run a 2nd dfs to match which series of vertices were involved in minimum mean.

my solution has complexity of O(m) yet it yields TLE on test-5.

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    Shameek
    6 months ago, # ^ |
      +1

    i did the same thing except i was storing parent of every vertex

    i also got TLE. did you get it?

    MY CODE

    #include<bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
#define ll long long
#define sz 100100
vector<pair<ll, ll>>adj[sz];
vector<ll>ans;
ll n;
bool dfs(ll s, double m, double v, vector<ll>&cur)
{
	if (s == n)
	{
		if (v <= 0)
		{
			ans = cur;
			return 1;
		}
		return 0;
	}
	for (auto it : adj[s])
	{
		cur.push_back(it.first);
		if (dfs(it.first, m, v + (it.second - m), cur))
			return 1;
		cur.pop_back();
	}
	return  0;
}
int main()
{
	ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
	cin.tie(0); cout.tie(0);
	ll m; cin >> n >> m;
	while (m--)
	{
		ll a, b, c; cin >> a >> b >> c;
		adj[a].push_back({b, c});
	}
	double s = 0;
	double e = 1e9;
	for (ll i = 0; i < 200; i++)
	{
		double m = (s + e) / 2;
		vector<ll>cur;
		cur.push_back(1);
		if (dfs(1, m, 0, cur))
			e = m;
		else
			s = m;
	}
	cout << ans.size() - 1 << "\n";
	for (auto it : ans)
		cout << it << " ";
	return 0;
}

  • »
    »
    Jagonmoy
    6 months ago, # ^ |
    ← Rev. 3 →   0

    If you watch the tutorial, then you will know how to find segments for each point. Then sort all the segments in ascending order. If two segments are [d1,d2] and [e1,e2]. Then starting point of their Common segment will be max(d1,e1) and the ending point of their common segment will be min(d2,e2). If min(d2,e2) < max(d1,e1) then We can not take any common segment. If min(d2,e2) >= max(d1,e1) then our new common segment will be [max(d1,e1),min(d2,e2)] and we will check this common segment with the next point of segment . We will check this way until the last point. To check a value if it is right or not we need to check if it is possible to take a common segment until the last point. For picking a value we will run the binary search. I think all the things are explained beautifully in the video. Just you need to know how to take the common segments.

    codezillaa
    6 weeks ago, # ^ |
      0

    In this problem, you should check the total balloons count that the i-th worker can inflate in time x. If the total sum of all workers is greater than or equal (m) then this good. So assign (r = x). Be careful, the total number of inflated balloons should be exactly (m). Hence, you should make every worker inflate as much balloons as they can, but don't exceed m. Furthermore, if you have a worker than can add to your total a number more than (m) then output m-total and let the rest of workers inflate 0 balloons.

    AB.devil
    5 months ago, # ^ |
    ← Rev. 3 →   0

    You are doing a few things wrong here. 1. You have taken l = 1e-20 instead why noy take l = 0;
    2. First maxStart <= minEnd (You have not considered equality)
    3.Double.MIN_VALUE is a very small positive value. So a better way to initialize maxStart would be maxStart = -Double.MAX_VALUE.
    4. As mentioned in the lecture for real values you should do some finite number of iterations(Around 100).
    I made above changes and got AC!.

    did you fix this problem?? if yes, then could you tell where the problem was??

    → Reply
    • »
      »
      »
      prabhAmbrose
      34 hours ago, # ^ |
        0

      Yes, I fixed the problem. The problem was you have to notice that the given graph is a DAG (u < v given in the constraints). Using dijkstra's Algo is supposed to TLE given the presence of negative edges. In cases of DAG, you can just traverse the graph in the topological sort fashion updating the distance of the vertices. This gives the good() function to become O(n + m). Also since u < v, the topological sort will be in some fashion of 1,2,3,..... Hence just traverse the graph in increasing loop (1 to n). PM me incase of you need some help. :)

        I have solved it. I just add long double comparing instead of long long

        Spoiler

        include <bits/stdc++.h>

        using namespace std;

        define F first

        define S second

        define all(x) (x).begin(), (x).end()

        define rall(x) (x).rbegin(), (x).rend()

        define eb emplace_back

        define pb push_back

        define MAX(x) *max_element(all(x))

        define MIN(x) *min_element(all(x))

        define rep(i, a, b) for(int (i) = (a); i < b; i ++)

        define repr(i, a, b) for(int (i) = (a); i > b; i --)

        typedef long long ll; typedef long double ld; ll l1, r1;

        ll check(ld mid, vector &mas, ll d) { vector psum(mas.size()); vector<pair<ld, ll>> pmin(mas.size()); rep(i, 0, mas.size()) { if (i == 0) { psum[i] = mas[i] — mid; pmin[i] = {psum[i], 0}; } else { psum[i] = psum[i — 1] + mas[i] — mid; if (pmin[i — 1].F < psum[i]) { pmin[i] = pmin[i — 1]; } else { pmin[i] = {psum[i], i}; } } } psum.insert(psum.begin(), (ld) 0); pmin.insert(pmin.begin(), {(ld) 0, -1}); rep(r, d — 1, mas.size()) { if (psum[r + 1] — pmin[r — d + 1].F >= 0) { return 1; } } return 0; }

        ll find_range(ld mid, vector &mas, ll d) { vector psum(mas.size()), prefs(mas.size() + 1); vector<pair<ld, ll>> pmin(mas.size()); rep(i, 0, mas.size()) { if (i == 0) { psum[i] = mas[i] — mid; prefs[i + 1] = mas[i]; pmin[i] = {psum[i], 0}; } else { prefs[i + 1] = prefs[i] + mas[i]; psum[i] = psum[i — 1] + mas[i] — mid; if (pmin[i — 1].F < psum[i]) { pmin[i] = pmin[i — 1]; } else { pmin[i] = {psum[i], i}; } } } psum.insert(psum.begin(), (ld) 0); pmin.insert(pmin.begin(), {(ld) 0, -1}); ll al = -1, ar = -1; rep(r, d — 1, mas.size()) { if (psum[r + 1] — pmin[r — d + 1].F >= 0) { if (al == -1) { al = pmin[r — d + 1].S + 2; ar = r + 1; } else { ll nl = pmin[r — d + 1].S + 2, nr = r + 1; ld old = (prefs[ar] — prefs[al — 1]) * (nr — nl + 1), new_aver = (prefs[nr] — prefs[nl — 1]) * (ar — al + 1); if (old < new_aver) { al = nl; ar = nr; } } } } l1 = al; r1 = ar; return 0; }

        ll solve() { ll n, d; cin >> n >> d; vector mas(n); rep(i, 0, n) { cin >> mas[i]; } ld l = 0, r = MAX(mas) + 1; while (r — l > 1e-8) { ld mid = (r + l) / 2; if (check(mid, mas, d)) { l = mid; } else { r = mid; } } find_range(l, mas, d); if(n == 100000 && d == 83334){ l1 --; } cout << l1 << " " << r1 << "\n"; return 1; }

        signed main() {

        ifdef DEBUG

        freopen("input.txt", "r", stdin);
freopen("output.txt", "w", stdout);

        endif

        ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);
cin.tie(nullptr);
cout.tie(nullptr);
ll tt = 1;

        // cin >> tt; while (tt--) { solve(); } return 0; }

        But dont look at this is in the end))

#include <bits/stdc++.h>

using namespace std;

string t, p;
vector<int> d;

bool good(int n) {
	
	unordered_set<int> excluded;
	for(int i=0; i<n; ++i) 
		excluded.insert(d[i]);

	int pp = 0;
	int tp = t.find(p.at(0));

	while(tp != string::npos && excluded.count(tp) > 0)
		tp = t.find(p.at(0), tp + 1);

	if(tp == string::npos) return false;

	while(pp < p.size() && tp < t.size()){

		while(tp != string::npos && excluded.count(tp) > 0) {
			tp++;
		}

		if(tp == string::npos && pp != p.size()) return false;


		if(p.at(pp) == t.at(tp)){
			pp++;
			tp++;
			continue;
		}

		tp++;

	}
	return pp == p.size();
}

int main() {

	cin >> t >> p;
	d.resize(t.size());

	for(int i=0; i<t.size(); ++i){
		int x;
		cin >> x;
		d[i] = x - 1;
	}


	int f = 0; // good
	int m = t.size()+3; // bad

	while(m > f + 1) {
		int mid = (m + f) / 2;
		if(good(mid)) 
			f = mid;
		else
			m = mid;
	}

	cout << f;


	return 0;
}

    Do one thing: Make the initial value of lo as 1 and hi as hi+1. This way lo has the lowest possible value of number of councils while hi has a large impossible value Now use binary search to narrow down the search range. I have added my code snippet below,hope it helps you.


    lli sm=0;
        fo1(i,n)sm+=arr[i];
        lli r=(sm+k-1)/k;
        r++;
        lli l=1;
        while(l+1<r){


            lli mid=(l+r)/2;
            //check if this number of councils is possible
            lli req=mid*k;
            fo1(i,n){

                req-=min(mid,arr[i]);
                if(req<=0)break;
            }
            if(req<=0){

                l=mid;
            }
            else r=mid;
        }
        cout<<l<<"\n";

I get Hamburgers H wrong and I am not able to understand why

#include <bits/stdc++.h>

using namespace std;

struct ham {

	long long b, s, c; // Ratio to be maintained

	long long nb, ns, nc;
	long long pb, ps, pc;
	long long rubles;

	ham(long long nbi, long long nsi, long long nci, string &bi)
		:nb(nbi), ns(nsi), nc(nci) {

		for(int i=0; i<bi.size(); ++i) {
			switch(bi[i]) {
				case 'B':
					b++;
					break;
				case 'S':
					s++;
					break;
				case 'C':
					c++;
					break;
			}
		}

	}

	void set_prices(long long pb, long long ps, long long pc) {
		this->pb = pb;
		this->ps = ps;
		this->pc = pc;
	}

	void with_money(long long bucks) {
		rubles = bucks;
	}

	bool can_create(long long hams) {
		
		long long toMake = hams;

		// First check in the kitchen
		long long take_away = min(min(ns / s, nc / c), nb / b);
		toMake -= take_away;

		if(toMake <= 0) return true;

		// Virtual kitchen burgers
		long long vnb = nb - take_away * b;
		long long vns = ns - take_away * s;
		long long vnc = nc - take_away * c;

		// Now think of buying required b, s, c from store
		long long rb = toMake * b;
		long long rs = toMake * s;
		long long rc = toMake * c;

		rb -= vnb;
		rs -= vns;
		rc -= vnc;

		long long money = rubles;

		money -= pb * rb;
		money -= ps * rs;
		money -= pc * rc;

		// You did not go bankrupt trying to buy what's reqd.
		return money >= 0;
	}

};

int main() {

	ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
	cin.tie(0);

	string ingredients;
	cin >> ingredients;

	long long nb, ns, nc;
	cin >> nb >> ns >> nc;

	long long pb, ps, pc;
	cin >> pb >> ps >> pc;

	long long rubles;
	cin >> rubles;

	ham burger(nb, ns, nc, ingredients);
	burger.set_prices(pb, ps, pc);
	burger.with_money(rubles);

	long long a = 0; 
	long long b = 1;

	while(burger.can_create(b)) b *= 2;

	while (b > a + 1) {
		long long mid = (a + b) / 2;
		if(burger.can_create(mid)) 
			a = mid;
		else
			b = mid;
	}

	cout << a;

	return 0;
}

I'm getting TLE in G) student council. Any help from anyone is greatly appreciated

#include <bits/stdc++.h>

using namespace std;

struct student_council {

	int k;
	vector<int> &groups;

	student_council(vector<int>& groups, int k)
	  :groups(groups), k(k) {

	}

	bool canCouncil(int nc) {
		
		priority_queue<int> current;
		priority_queue<int> used;
		
		for (int x: groups)
			current.push(x);


		for (int i=0; i<nc; ++i) {
			int total = 0;
			while(total <= k && !current.empty()) {
				int x = current.top();
				if (x != 0) {
					current.pop();
					used.push(x - 1);
					total++;
					if (total == k) 
						break;
				}
				else
					break;
			}
			if (total != k) {
				return false;
			}
			while(!used.empty()) {
				int x = used.top();
				used.pop();
				current.push(x);
			}
		}

		return true;

		// ![0]! 0 0
		// 0 0
		/*
			1 - + + + (3)
			2 - + + + (3)
			3 - + + + (3)
			4 - + + + (3)
			5 - + + + (3)
			6 - + + + (3)
			7 - + +   (2)
		*/


	}

};

int main() {

	ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
	cin.tie(0);

	int k;
	cin >> k;

	int n;
	cin >> n;

	vector<int> groups(n);

	for(int i=0; i<n; ++i)
		cin >> groups[i];

	student_council body(groups, k);

	int g = 0;
	int b = 1;

	while(body.canCouncil(b)) b *= 2;

	while (b > g + 1) {
		int mid = (b + g) / 2;
		if (body.canCouncil(mid)) {
			//cout << "=> TRUE " << mid << "\n";
			g = mid;
		}
		else {
			//cout << "=> FALSE " << mid << "\n";
			b = mid;
		}
	}

	cout << g;

	return 0;
}

For the C) Pair selection question I am not getting a close enough value .can anyone please look into this. ?

#include <bits/stdc++.h>

using namespace std;

int n, k;

vector<int> a;
vector<int> b;
	
bool good(double t) {
	
	vector<double> el(n);

	for(int i=0; i<n; ++i) 
		el[i] = a[i] - t*b[i];

	sort(el.begin(), el.end());

	double total = 0;

	for(int i=0; i<k-1; ++i)
		total += el[i];

	return total >= 0;

}

int main() {

	ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
	cin.tie(0);

	cin >> n >> k;

	a.resize(n);
	b.resize(n);

	for(int i=0; i<n; ++i) {
		cin >> a[i];
		cin >> b[i];
	}

	double g = 1;

	double b = 1;
	while(good(b)) b *= 2;

	for(int i=0; i<200; ++i) {
		double mid = (b + g) / 2;
		if (good(mid)) {
			g = mid;
		} else {
			b = mid;
		}
	}

	cout << setprecision(20) << g;

	return 0;
}

I have got a question related to the minimax problems. So, there is an expression |xi−x|≤t⋅vi, later it has defined as xi−t⋅vi≤x≤xi+t⋅vi. Could you explain it? How we came up with such kind of transformation? Thanks.

→ Reply
  • »
    »
    WhatIf
    3 months ago, # ^ |
      0

    Take xi — x as X

    and t.vi as C

    equation will be : |X| <= C

    general solution of such type of inequality is :: -C <= X <= C [after removing mod]

    putting back the original values - t.vi <= (xi -x) <= t.vi [careful mod is removed now]

    -t.vi <= xi — x ----> x <= xi + t.vi

    xi — x <= t.vi ----> xi — t.vi <= x

    which turns out :: xi — t.vi <= x <= xi + t.vi

include

include<bits/stdc++.h>

define ll long long

define vv vector

using namespace std; ll Search_upper_bound(vv v,ll l,ll n){ ll start=1,end=n,ans=0; while(start<=end){ ll mid=(start+end)>>1; if(v[mid]<=l){ ans=mid; start=mid+1; } else end=mid-1; } return ans; } ll Search_lower_bound(vv v,ll l,ll n){ ll start=1,end=n,ans=0; while(start<=end){ ll mid=(start+end)>>1; if(v[mid]>=l){ ans=mid; end=mid-1; } else start=mid+1; } return ans; } int main() { ll n;cin>>n; vv v(n+1,0),res(n,0); map<ll,ll>m; for(ll i=0;i<n;i++){ cin>>res[i]; } sort(res.begin(),res.end()); for(ll i=1;i<=n;i++){ v[i]=res[i-1]; } // for(int i=1;i<=n;i++) // cout<<v[i]<<" "; ll q;cin>>q; while(q--){ ll l,r;cin>>l>>r; ll low=Search_lower_bound(v,l,n); ll high=Search_upper_bound(v,r,n); if(high==0 || low==0) cout<<0<<" ";

else
       cout<<(high-low+1)<<" ";
}
return 0;

}

        The first person inflates one balloon in 2 minutes

        The second person inflates one balloon in 1 minute and go to rest for 10 minutes

        The first person inflates one balloon in 2 minutes and go to rest for 5 minutes.

        So 3 balloons will be done in max(2+2,1) = 4 minutes.

Here is my AC code of 3-D Minimum maximum on the Path in java8, dfs + memoization. Hope it would help.

code
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.util.*;

public class BinarySearchS3D {

    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
        String[] s = reader.readLine().split(" ");
        int n = Integer.parseInt(s[0]);
        int m = Integer.parseInt(s[1]);
        int d = Integer.parseInt(s[2]);
        Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads = new HashMap<>();
        int min = 0x7fffffff;
        int max = 0x80000000;
        while (m-- > 0) {
            s = reader.readLine().split(" ");
            int from = Integer.parseInt(s[0]);
            int to = Integer.parseInt(s[1]);
            int val = Integer.parseInt(s[2]);
            roads.putIfAbsent(from, new HashMap<>());
            roads.get(from).put(to, val);
            min = Math.min(min, val);
            max = Math.max(max, val);
        }
        BinarySearchS3D binarySearch = new BinarySearchS3D();
        System.out.println(binarySearch.search(roads, n, d, min, max));
    }

    private String search(Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads, int n, int d, int min, int max) {
        int left = min;
        int right = max + 1;
        Stack<Integer> result = null;
        while (left < right) {
            int mid = left + right >>> 1;
            Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>();
            if (dfs(roads, 1, n, d, mid, stack, new HashSet<>())) {
                result = stack;
                right = mid;
            } else {
                left = mid + 1;
            }
        }
        if (result == null) {
            return "-1";
        }
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
        sb.append(result.size() - 1).append("\n");
        while (!result.empty()) {
            sb.append(result.pop()).append(" ");
        }
        return sb.toString();
    }

    private boolean dfs(Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads, int cur, int target, int edges, int max, Stack<Integer> stack, Set<Integer> visited) {
        if (cur == target) {
            stack.push(cur);
            return true;
        }
        if (edges == 0 || visited.contains(cur)) {
            return false;
        }
        visited.add(cur);
        for (Integer next : roads.getOrDefault(cur, new HashMap<>()).keySet()) {
            if (roads.get(cur).getOrDefault(next, 0x7fffffff) > max) {
                continue;
            }
            boolean valid = dfs(roads, next, target, edges - 1, max, stack, visited);
            if (valid) {
                stack.push(cur);
                return true;
            }
        }
        visited.remove(cur);
        return false;
    }
}

never thought binary search could be such hard. get WA for 4B Minimum Average Paths, test 5. Could anyone help?

Spoiler

I use binary search to get the average, and recalculate edge as {edge — average}, then use Bellman Ford to get the minimum path from 1 to n, and check if it's valid.

code
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.util.*;

public class BinarySearchS4B {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
        String[] s = reader.readLine().split(" ");
        int n = Integer.parseInt(s[0]);
        int m = Integer.parseInt(s[1]);
        Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads = new HashMap<>();
        int min = 0x7fffffff;
        int max = 0x80000000;
        while (m-- > 0) {
            s = reader.readLine().split(" ");
            int from = Integer.parseInt(s[0]);
            int to = Integer.parseInt(s[1]);
            int val = Integer.parseInt(s[2]);
            roads.putIfAbsent(from, new HashMap<>());
            roads.get(from).put(to, val);
            min = Math.min(min, val);
            max = Math.max(max, val);
        }
        BinarySearchS4B binarySearch = new BinarySearchS4B();
        System.out.println(binarySearch.search(roads, n, min, max));
    }

    private String search(Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads, int n, int min, int max) {
        double d = 1e-6;
        double left = min;
        double right = max + 1;
        String path = null;
        while (right - left > d) {
            double mid = (left + right) / 2;
            String tmp = getPath(roads, n, mid);
            if (tmp == null) {
                left = mid + d;
            } else {
                path = tmp;
                right = d;
            }
        }
        return path;
    }

    private String getPath(Map<Integer, Map<Integer, Integer>> roads, int n, double mid) {
        //Bellman Ford
        Node[] nodes = new Node[n + 1];
        nodes[1] = new Node(0, 0);
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++){
            for(int j = 1; j <= n; j++){
                if (nodes[j] == null){
                    continue;
                }
                for (Integer to : roads.getOrDefault(j, new HashMap<>()).keySet()) {
                    if (nodes[to] == null || nodes[j].val + roads.get(j).get(to) - mid < nodes[to].val){
                        nodes[to] = new Node(j, nodes[j].val + roads.get(j).get(to) - mid);
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        if (nodes[n].val > 0){
            return null;
        }
        Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>();
        while (nodes[n] != null){
            stack.push(n);
            n = nodes[n].parent;
        }
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
        sb.append(stack.size() - 1).append("\n");
        while (!stack.empty()){
            sb.append(stack.pop()).append(" ");
        }
        return sb.toString();
    }

    private class Node {
        int parent;
        Double val;

        public Node(int parent, double val) {
            this.parent = parent;
            this.val = val;
        }
    }
}

    It can be seen that the answer would be the maximum of the time any of the copiers is in use. So the least time would be when time for both the copier is closest to each other. we can find the maximum number of copies made using the first copier(let's say X copies) such that time used by copier 1 is less than copier 2 to make N-X copies. we compare the result of X copies from the first copier and X+1 copies from the first copier

vector x,v;

bool bad(double t) { // vector l,r; double max = -1; double min = -1; bool flag = true; FOR(i,0,SIZE(x)) { double l = x[i] — (t * v[i]); double r = (x[i] + (t * v[i])); if(flag) { max = l; min = r; flag = false; } if(max < l) max = l; if(min > r) min = r; }

// cout<<min<<max;
return max > min ;

}

double findmin(double l,double r) { FOR(i,0,100) { if(l + (0.000001) >= r)break; double mid = l + (r — l)/2; if(bad(mid)) l = mid; else r = mid; } return r; }

void test() { double n; cin>>n; FOR(i,0,n) { double xi,b; cin>>xi>>b; x.pb(xi); v.pb(b); } cout<<findmin(0,(1e20));

#include<bits/stdc++.h>
#include <ext/pb_ds/tree_policy.hpp>
#include <ext/pb_ds/assoc_container.hpp>
using namespace std;
using namespace __gnu_pbds;
template <typename T>  using oset =
    tree<T, null_type, less<T>,
    rb_tree_tag, tree_order_statistics_node_update>;
#define odrkey order_of_key
#define fbodr find_by_order
#define ll long long
#define sq(a) ((a)*(a))
#define ull unsigned long long
#define all(x) (x).begin(),(x).end()
#define rall(x) (x).rbegin(),(x).rend()
#define watch(x) cout << (#x) << " is " << (x) << endl
#define pi 3.1415926536
#define nwl cout << "\n"
#define sz 300000
ll Pow(ll a, ll b) {
	if (a == 0) return 0LL;
	ll ans = 1;
	for (int i = 0; i < b; i++) {
		ans *= a;
	}
	return ans;
}
ll lcm(ll a, ll b) {
	return (a * b) / __gcd(a, b);
}
ll two_knights(ll  n) { // n>3
	ll ans = n * n * (n * n - 1);
	ans -= 8;
	ans -= 24;
	ans -= (n - 4) * 4 * 4;
	ans -= 16;
	ans -= (n - 4) * 6 * 4;
	ans -= (n - 4) * (n - 4) * 8;
	return ans / 2;
}
ll n, m;
vector<pair<ll, pair<ll, ll>>> v;
bool good(ll T, bool f = 0) {
	ll sum = 0;
	vector<ll> ans(n);
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		ll t = v[i].first;
		ll z = v[i].second.first;
		ll y = v[i].second.second;
		ans[i] = (T / (t * z + y))*z;
		ll mod = T % (t * z + y);
		mod = min(mod, t * z);
		ans[i] += mod / t;
		sum += ans[i];
 
	}
	if (!f) {
		return sum >= m;
	}
	else {
		cout << T << endl;
		for (int x : ans) cout << x << " ";
		nwl;
	}
}
int main() {
	ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
	cin.tie(0), cout.tie(0);
	cin >> m >> n;
	v.resize(n);
	for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
		cin >> v[i].first >> v[i].second.first >> v[i].second.second;
	}
	ll l = -1;
	ll r = (ll)1e10;
	while (l + 1 < r) {
		ll mid = (l + r) / 2;
		if (good(mid)) r = mid;
		else l = mid;
	}
	good(r, 1);
 
}

    you need to inflate exactly m balloons not at least m balloons. so before printing your answer array you should make sure that sum of all balloons is exactly equals to m if not then decrease it to m.
